description: A list of N2 vocabulary related to daily life, routines, and common situations.

items.exampleSentence: このアパートは単身者向けの世帯が多い。
items.exampleTranslation: This apartment building has many households for single people.
items.notes: Refers to a family unit living together.

items.meaning: food, clothing, and shelter; the necessities of life
items.exampleSentence: 健康的な衣食住は幸福の基本だ。
items.exampleTranslation: Healthy food, clothing, and shelter are the basis of happiness.
items.notes: A compound word: 衣 (clothing), 食 (food), 住 (housing).

items.exampleSentence: 週末は家事を手伝うようにしている。
items.exampleTranslation: I try to help with the housework on weekends.
items.notes: The work needed to run a home.

items.exampleSentence: 育児と仕事の両立は大変だ。
items.exampleTranslation: Balancing childcare and work is tough.
items.notes: The process of caring for children.

items.exampleSentence: 都会では近所付き合いが少なくなっている。
items.exampleTranslation: In the city, relations with neighbors are decreasing.
items.notes: The social interaction and relationships among neighbors.

items.exampleSentence: 一週間分の献立を考える。
items.exampleTranslation: I think about the menu for a week.
items.notes: A list of the dishes to be served at a meal.

items.exampleSentence: バランスの取れた栄養が大切だ。
items.exampleTranslation: Balanced nutrition is important.
items.notes: The substances that you take into your body as food and the way that they influence your health.

items.exampleSentence: このソースは独特の風味がある。
items.exampleTranslation: This sauce has a unique flavor.
items.notes: The particular taste of a food or drink.

items.meaning: to taste, to savor, to relish, to experience
items.exampleSentence: ゆっくりと食事を味わう時間も必要だ。
items.exampleTranslation: It's also necessary to have time to slowly savor a meal.
items.notes: Can be used for both food and experiences (e.g., 雰囲気を味わう - to savor the atmosphere).

items.exampleSentence: 食品を扱う際は衛生に注意してください。
items.exampleTranslation: Please pay attention to hygiene when handling food.
items.notes: The practice of keeping yourself and your surroundings clean in order to prevent illness or disease.

items.exampleSentence: 新しい住まいを探している。
items.exampleTranslation: I am looking for a new place to live.
items.notes: A slightly more formal or literary word for 'house' or 'home'.

items.exampleSentence: このアパートは間取りがいい。
items.exampleTranslation: This apartment has a good floor plan.
items.notes: Describes the arrangement of rooms in a house, e.g., 2LDK (2 bedrooms, living, dining, kitchen).

items.meaning: exposure to the sun, sunny place
items.exampleSentence: 私の部屋は南向きで日当たりがいい。
items.exampleTranslation: My room faces south and gets good sunlight.
items.notes: A key factor when choosing a place to live in Japan.

items.exampleSentence: この家は収納スペースがたくさんある。
items.exampleTranslation: This house has a lot of storage space.
items.notes: The act of putting things in a container for future use, or a space for this.

items.exampleSentence: 休日はDIYで棚を作った。
items.exampleTranslation: I made a shelf with DIY on my day off.
items.notes: An English acronym commonly used in Japanese.

items.exampleSentence: 日本ではごみをきちんと分別しなければならない。
items.exampleTranslation: In Japan, you have to separate garbage properly.
items.notes: Garbage separation rules are often very strict and vary by municipality.

items.exampleSentence: ペットボトルはリサイクルに出してください。
items.exampleTranslation: Please put plastic bottles out for recycling.
items.notes: The process of converting waste materials into new materials and objects.

items.exampleSentence: 電気代を節約するために、こまめに電気を消す。
items.exampleTranslation: To save on electricity bills, I turn off lights frequently.
items.notes: The act of using less of something, like money, energy, or time.

items.exampleSentence: 今月は予期せぬ出費が多かった。
items.exampleTranslation: There were a lot of unexpected expenses this month.
items.notes: The money that you spend on something.

items.exampleSentence: 毎日家計簿をつけて、収支を管理している。
items.exampleTranslation: I keep a household account book every day to manage income and expenses.
items.notes: A traditional Japanese method of budgeting and tracking expenses.

items.exampleSentence: 約束の時間までカフェで時間を潰した。
items.exampleTranslation: I killed time at a cafe until the appointment time.

items.exampleSentence: 面接に行く前に、身だしなみを整える。
items.exampleTranslation: Before going to an interview, I fix my appearance.
items.notes: Refers to taking care of one's appearance to make a good impression.

items.exampleSentence: 彼女はいつもおしゃれな服を着ている。
items.exampleTranslation: She always wears stylish clothes.
items.notes: Can be used as a noun (a stylish person) or an adjective.

items.exampleSentence: 今年の冬は、長いコートが流行している。
items.exampleTranslation: Long coats are in fashion this winter.
items.notes: Also used for the spread of diseases (e.g., インフルエンザの流行).

items.exampleSentence: このセーター、試着してもいいですか。
items.exampleTranslation: May I try on this sweater?
items.notes: 試着室 (shichakushitsu) is a fitting room.

items.exampleSentence: 家に帰ったら、まず部屋着に着替える。
items.exampleTranslation: When I get home, the first thing I do is change into loungewear.
items.notes: A compound of 着る (to wear) and 替える (to change).

items.exampleSentence: 彼女は毎朝、化粧に30分かける。
items.exampleTranslation: She spends 30 minutes on her makeup every morning.
items.notes: 化粧を落とす (keshou o otosu) means to remove makeup.

items.exampleSentence: 毎朝、公園を散歩するのが日課だ。
items.exampleTranslation: It's my daily routine to take a walk in the park every morning.
items.notes: A leisurely walk for pleasure or exercise.

items.exampleSentence: 私の趣味は写真を撮ることです。
items.exampleTranslation: My hobby is taking pictures.
items.notes: An activity done regularly in one's leisure time for pleasure.

items.exampleSentence: この町には娯楽施設が少ない。
items.exampleTranslation: There are few entertainment facilities in this town.
items.notes: Activities that people do for fun and relaxation.

items.exampleSentence: 電車の中では、いつも読書をしている。
items.exampleTranslation: I always do some reading on the train.
items.notes: Specifically refers to the act of reading books for pleasure or study.

items.exampleSentence: 友達に誕生日のお祝いの手紙を書いた。
items.exampleTranslation: I wrote a birthday celebration letter to my friend.
items.notes: A written message from one person to another, usually sent by post.

items.meaning: looking after a house during someone's absence
items.exampleSentence: 両親が旅行中、家で留守番をしていた。
items.exampleTranslation: While my parents were on a trip, I was looking after the house.
items.notes: Can also refer to the person who stays behind.

items.exampleSentence: インターネットで注文した商品が宅配便で届いた。
items.exampleTranslation: The product I ordered online arrived by courier.
items.notes: A very common and convenient service in Japan.

items.exampleSentence: 今夜は疲れたから、ピザの出前を取ろう。
items.exampleTranslation: I'm tired tonight, so let's order pizza for delivery.
items.notes: Traditionally associated with noodle shops, but now used more broadly.

items.exampleSentence: 一人暮らしを始めてから、毎日自炊している。
items.exampleTranslation: Since I started living alone, I cook for myself every day.
items.notes: The opposite is 外食 (gaishoku), eating out.

items.exampleSentence: 金曜の夜は、家族で外食することが多い。
items.exampleTranslation: On Friday nights, my family often eats out.
items.notes: The opposite is 自炊 (jisui), cooking for oneself.

items.exampleSentence: 忘年会のための宴会を予約した。
items.exampleTranslation: I booked a banquet for the year-end party.
items.notes: Often involves a formal dinner with drinks, common in Japanese work culture.

items.exampleSentence: 仕事の後に、同僚と飲み会に行った。
items.exampleTranslation: After work, I went to a drinking party with my colleagues.
items.notes: A very common social gathering in Japan, especially among coworkers.

items.exampleSentence: 新入社員のための歓迎会が開かれた。
items.exampleTranslation: A welcome party was held for the new employees.
items.notes: A party to welcome a new person to a group or company. The opposite is 送別会 (soubetsukai), a farewell party.

items.exampleSentence: 退職する同僚のために送別会を開いた。
items.exampleTranslation: We held a farewell party for a colleague who is retiring.
items.notes: A party to say goodbye to someone who is leaving a job or place. The opposite is 歓迎会 (kangeikai), a welcome party.

items.exampleSentence: 今日の飲み会は割り勘にしよう。
items.exampleTranslation: Let's split the bill for today's drinking party.
items.notes: A very common practice in Japan for informal gatherings.

items.meaning: to treat (someone) to a meal, drink, etc.
items.exampleSentence: 今日は給料日だから、私がおごるよ。
items.exampleTranslation: It's payday today, so it's my treat.
items.notes: The person being treated is marked with に (e.g., 友達に昼食をおごる).

items.meaning: a feast, a treat, a fine meal
items.exampleSentence: 誕生日なので、母がごちそうを作ってくれた。
items.exampleTranslation: Because it was my birthday, my mother made a feast for me.
items.notes: ごちそうさまでした (gochisou sama deshita) is a set phrase said after a meal to thank the host/cook.

items.exampleSentence: 今日は少し体調が悪い。
items.exampleTranslation: I'm not feeling very well today.
items.notes: 体調を崩す (taichou o kuzusu) means to get sick.

items.exampleSentence: 年に一度、健康診断を受けている。
items.exampleTranslation: I get a health check-up once a year.
items.notes: Often provided by companies or municipalities in Japan.

items.exampleSentence: 風邪の症状には、熱や咳がある。
items.exampleTranslation: Symptoms of a cold include fever and a cough.
items.notes: A physical or mental feature that is regarded as indicating a condition of disease.

items.exampleSentence: 医者に診察してもらう。
items.exampleTranslation: I will have a doctor examine me.
items.notes: The process where a doctor examines a patient.

items.exampleSentence: 虫歯の治療のために歯医者に行く。
items.exampleTranslation: I'm going to the dentist for treatment of a cavity.
items.notes: The management and care of a patient to combat disease or disorder.

items.exampleSentence: 医者に処方箋を書いてもらい、薬局で薬を買った。
items.exampleTranslation: I had the doctor write me a prescription and bought the medicine at a pharmacy.
items.notes: An instruction written by a medical practitioner that authorizes a patient to be provided a medicine or treatment.

items.exampleSentence: 処方箋を持って薬局へ行く。
items.exampleTranslation: I'm going to the pharmacy with my prescription.
items.notes: A place where prescription drugs are sold.

items.exampleSentence: この薬には眠くなるという副作用がある。
items.exampleTranslation: This medicine has the side effect of making you sleepy.
items.notes: An unintended secondary effect of a drug or medical treatment.

items.exampleSentence: 十分な睡眠をとることが健康に良い。
items.exampleTranslation: Getting enough sleep is good for your health.
items.notes: 睡眠不足 (suimin busoku) means lack of sleep.

items.exampleSentence: 最近、寝不足で頭が痛い。
items.exampleTranslation: Recently, I have a headache from lack of sleep.
items.notes: The state of not having had enough sleep.

items.exampleSentence: 長時間の運転で疲労がたまった。
items.exampleTranslation: Fatigue has built up from the long drive.
items.notes: A feeling of extreme physical or mental tiredness.

items.exampleSentence: 仕事でストレスがたまっている。
items.exampleTranslation: I'm stressed out from work.
items.notes: ストレス解消 (sutoresu kaishou) means stress relief.

items.exampleSentence: 気分転換に散歩でもしませんか。
items.exampleTranslation: How about we go for a walk for a change of pace?
items.notes: An activity that you do to take your mind off your problems.

items.exampleSentence: 週末は釣りに行って気晴らしをする。
items.exampleTranslation: On weekends, I go fishing for recreation.
items.notes: Something you do to relax and stop worrying.

items.exampleSentence: 仕事の合間にコーヒーを飲んで息抜きする。
items.exampleTranslation: I take a breather by drinking coffee during my work break.

items.meaning: at leisure, in a relaxed manner, carefree
items.exampleSentence: 休みの日は家でのんびり過ごすのが好きだ。
items.exampleTranslation: I like to spend my days off relaxing at home.
items.notes: Describes a state of being relaxed and without hurry.

items.meaning: to relax, to make oneself at home
items.exampleSentence: 自分の部屋で音楽を聴きながらくつろぐのが好きだ。
items.exampleTranslation: I like to relax in my room while listening to music.
items.notes: Implies a sense of comfort and ease.

items.exampleSentence: 毎日お風呂に入って一日の疲れを取る。
items.exampleTranslation: I take a bath every day to relieve the day's fatigue.
items.notes: Taking a bath is a very common daily ritual in Japan.

items.exampleSentence: 朝は時間がないので、シャワーを浴びるだけだ。
items.exampleTranslation: I don't have time in the morning, so I just take a shower.
items.notes: シャワーを浴びる (shawaa o abiru) means 'to take a shower'.

items.exampleSentence: 毎食後、きちんと歯を磨きましょう。
items.exampleTranslation: Let's brush our teeth properly after every meal.
items.notes: A fundamental part of daily hygiene.

items.exampleSentence: 最近は男性向けの化粧品も増えている。
items.exampleTranslation: Recently, cosmetics for men are also increasing.
items.notes: Products used for makeup and skin care.

items.exampleSentence: お風呂の後、ドライヤーで髪を乾かす。
items.exampleTranslation: After a bath, I dry my hair with a hairdryer.

items.exampleSentence: 毎朝6時に目覚まし時計をセットしている。
items.exampleTranslation: I set my alarm clock for 6 a.m. every morning.
items.notes: A clock that you can set to wake you up.

items.exampleSentence: 今朝は寝坊して、電車に乗り遅れた。
items.exampleTranslation: I overslept this morning and missed the train.
items.notes: The act of sleeping later than intended.

items.meaning: staying up late, keeping late hours
items.exampleSentence: 昨日は映画を見て夜更かししてしまった。
items.exampleTranslation: I stayed up late watching a movie yesterday.
items.notes: The act of staying awake until late at night.

items.exampleSentence: 試験の前日に徹夜で勉強した。
items.exampleTranslation: I pulled an all-nighter to study the day before the exam.
items.notes: Staying awake through the entire night.

items.exampleSentence: 家で犬をペットとして飼っている。
items.exampleTranslation: I have a dog as a pet at home.
items.notes: An animal kept for companionship or pleasure.

items.exampleSentence: 部屋に植物を置くと、空気がきれいになる気がする。
items.exampleTranslation: I feel like the air becomes cleaner when I put plants in my room.
items.notes: A living organism of the kind exemplified by trees, shrubs, herbs, grasses, ferns, and mosses.

items.exampleSentence: 趣味はガーデニングで、庭で野菜を育てています。
items.exampleTranslation: My hobby is gardening, and I grow vegetables in my yard.
items.notes: The activity of tending and cultivating a garden.

items.exampleSentence: 春になったので、部屋の模様替えをした。
items.exampleTranslation: Since it's spring, I rearranged the furniture in my room.
items.notes: Changing the layout or decoration of a room.

items.meaning: tidying up and keeping things in order
items.exampleSentence: 年末に部屋を整理整頓する。
items.exampleTranslation: I will tidy up my room at the end of the year.
items.notes: A key concept in Japanese organizing, often translated as 'Sort and Set in Order'.

items.exampleSentence: ジョギングは私の毎朝の日課です。
items.exampleTranslation: Jogging is my daily morning routine.
items.notes: A task or activity that is done regularly every day.

items.exampleSentence: 今週のスケジュールを確認する。
items.exampleTranslation: I'll check this week's schedule.
items.notes: A plan for carrying out a process or procedure, giving lists of intended events and times.

items.exampleSentence: 大学時代、コンビニでアルバイトをしていた。
items.exampleTranslation: I had a part-time job at a convenience store during my university days.
items.notes: From the German word 'Arbeit' (work). Often shortened to バイト (baito).

items.exampleSentence: 毎日電車で1時間かけて通勤している。
items.exampleTranslation: I commute for one hour by train every day.
items.notes: The journey between one's home and place of work.

items.exampleSentence: 私の弟はバスで通学している。
items.exampleTranslation: My younger brother commutes to school by bus.
items.notes: The journey between one's home and school.

items.exampleSentence: 朝の通勤ラッシュは避けたい。
items.exampleTranslation: I want to avoid the morning commute rush hour.
items.notes: Refers to the peak time when public transport is crowded.

items.exampleSentence: 毎朝、満員電車に乗るのは大変だ。
items.exampleTranslation: It's tough riding a crowded train every morning.
items.notes: A common experience for commuters in large Japanese cities.

items.exampleSentence: 次の駅で地下鉄に乗り換えます。
items.exampleTranslation: I will transfer to the subway at the next station.
items.notes: The act of changing from one vehicle or transportation line to another.

items.exampleSentence: 会社の近くまで、定期券で通っている。
items.exampleTranslation: I commute to near my office with a commuter pass.
items.notes: A pass that allows unlimited travel between two specified stations for a set period.

items.exampleSentence: 寝坊して、学校に遅刻してしまった。
items.exampleTranslation: I overslept and was late for school.

items.exampleSentence: 週末にスーパーへ買い物に行く。
items.exampleTranslation: I go shopping at the supermarket on the weekend.

items.exampleSentence: 駅前の商店街はいつもにぎやかだ。
items.exampleTranslation: The shopping street in front of the station is always lively.

items.exampleSentence: スーパーで卵の特売をやっている。
items.exampleTranslation: The supermarket is having a special sale on eggs.
items.notes: Selling goods at a lower price than usual for a limited time.

items.exampleSentence: デパ地下では、いろいろな食品の試食ができる。
items.exampleTranslation: In the department store basement food hall, you can sample various foods.
items.notes: The act of tasting a small amount of food to see what it is like.

items.exampleSentence: 商品を持ってレジに並ぶ。
items.exampleTranslation: I take the items and line up at the cash register.
items.notes: Short for キャッシュレジスター (kyasshu rejisutaa).

items.exampleSentence: お会計、お願いします。
items.exampleTranslation: The check, please.
items.notes: Also means 'accounting' in a business context.

items.exampleSentence: 支払いはクレジットカードでできますか。
items.exampleTranslation: Can I pay by credit card?

items.exampleSentence: この店は現金しか使えません。
items.exampleTranslation: This shop only accepts cash.
items.notes: Money in the form of coins or banknotes.

items.exampleSentence: 経費で払うので、領収書をください。
items.exampleTranslation: I'll pay with expenses, so please give me a receipt.
items.notes: A formal document acknowledging that a sum of money has been received.

items.exampleSentence: 1万円札で払ったら、お釣りが多かった。
items.exampleTranslation: When I paid with a 10,000 yen bill, I got a lot of change back.
items.notes: The money returned to a buyer after they have paid for something with more money than it costs.

items.exampleSentence: 給料は銀行口座に振り込まれる。
items.exampleTranslation: My salary is transferred into my bank account.
items.notes: An arrangement with a bank to keep your money there.

items.exampleSentence: 将来のために、毎月預金している。
items.exampleTranslation: I deposit money every month for the future.
items.notes: Money placed in a bank account.

items.exampleSentence: 海外旅行のために貯金している。
items.exampleTranslation: I am saving money for an overseas trip.
items.notes: Often used interchangeably with 預金 (yokin), but 貯金 can also refer to saving money at home (not in a bank).

items.meaning: to transfer money (to a bank account)
items.exampleSentence: 家賃を大家さんの口座に振り込む。
items.exampleTranslation: I will transfer the rent to the landlord's account.
items.notes: A common way to pay bills and salaries in Japan.

items.kana: こうきょうりょうきん
items.exampleSentence: 毎月、銀行口座から公共料金が引き落とされる。
items.exampleTranslation: Utility bills are automatically withdrawn from my bank account every month.
items.notes: Charges for services such as electricity, gas, and water.
